awd_titl_txt: US-Israel Collab: Are parasites in complex communities more evolvable? Bridging ecology and evolution with computational modeling and rodent-bacteria evolution experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a growing appreciation that evolution plays a central role in the emergence and reemergence of infectious diseases. However, our understanding of why some pathogens and parasites rapidly adapt to novel environments, while others don't, remains incomplete. This ability of some parasites to evolve rapidly (i.e., evolvability) allows them to "jump" into infecting new host species. This project will examine whether and how some natural communities of interacting animals and microbes generate conditions that favor the evolution of evolvability. Understanding why variation in evolvability arises can help to identify potential emerging diseases and inform management strategies that reduce their ability to spread. It makes intuitive sense that greater evolvability is beneficial for the parasite, but evolvability does not directly increase the parasite's reproduction or survivorship. Thus, it is less clear how it arises or is maintained in populations. Results from computer simulations suggest that evolvability is advantageous in unpredictable and constantly changing environments. The project uses computer simulations of host-parasite coevolution as well as field and laboratory experiments using a natural bacteria-rodent system to identify specific aspects of parasite ecology that promote or hinder the evolution of evolvability. This project is a collaboration with Israeli scientists.  It will develop new computational tools for the scientific community, materials for undergraduate and secondary school classrooms, as well as teacher training and research experience for teachers in Michigan. 

Parasite populations typically evolve in complex communities, where multiple host species have overlapping ranges, and multiple infections occur within a single host. This project will address four central aims: 1) quantifying the effect of host heterogeneity on parasite evolvability and diversity; 2) measuring how host heterogeneity influences the prevalence and intensity of coinfection by multiple parasite species; 3) identifying the effect of parasite coinfection on evolvability and diversity; and 4) quantifying the combined effects of host heterogeneity and parasite coinfection on evolvability and diversity. Experiments using Avida, a computational platform where digital hosts and parasites evolve in an open-ended fashion, will be complemented by a combination of field-site sampling and laboratory evolution experiments using Bartonella parasites and their wild rodent hosts in the Israeli Negev Dunes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Parasites, including pathogens, have complex interactions with the animals they infect, which influence whether they will spread and cause disease. This project used a combination of experiments with bacteria and digital organisms to examine how the ability of parasites to evolve shapes and is shaped by different demographic factors and host environments.

 

One study system used Bartonella bacteria that are parasites that infect several rodent species in the Negev Desert in Israel. A year-long laboratory experiment was conducted to examine how these bacteria evolve in response to different host environments. The collaborating team of Israeli researchers passaged Bartonella through a series of individuals from one rodent species, a second rodent species, or alternating between the two species. This team of US researchers worked with the Israeli scientists to design the experiment and analyze the genetic changes in the bacteria. Instead of the Bartonella that alternated hosts evolving most rapidly, evolution was dominated by mutations that improved the parasite’s fitness in the less favorable gerbil species, no matter how often they encountered this host. Repetitive sequences in the Bartonella genome that mutate at especially high rates were responsible for this adaptation. Similar sequences have been shown to allow pathogens to rapidly evolve to escape host immune responses. This study suggests that they are also important for pathogens evolving to infect new hosts.

 

Computational experiments with digital hosts and parasites in the Avida artificial life system showed that hosts evolved a surprisingly analogous ability to evade infection of coevolving parasites by switching computational functions through single point mutations. Using this artificial model system of coevolution, experiments were conducted to distinguish the drivers of increased phenotypic diversity and functional complexity of host-parasite communities. Specifically, these experiments compared the effect of complexity within the abiotic environment (e.g., the variety of distinct nutrients) and complexity within the biotic environment (e.g., the variety of distinct ways that hosts and parasites could evolve resistance and infectivity). Coevolution drove substantially higher complexity in every case and produced comparable levels of diversity to what evolved in abiotically complex environments. These observations inspired further work that showed how to algorithmically harness the benefits of complex biotic and abiotic environments in microbial adaptive lab evolution (ALE) experiments, where these kinds of ecological interactions are usually lacking. Studies were also performed to directly investigate the evolution of evolvability in digital organisms. Multiple ways to increase evolvability simultaneously evolved when populations were challenged by constantly shifting environments, like those containing parasites. Most strikingly, information about the kinds of past environments populations experienced was detectable by examining mutants of the adapted organisms (i.e., their mutational neighborhoods).

 

Laboratory experiments with E. coli were used to study the effects of genetic diversity and population bottlenecks on the dynamics of bacterial evolution. The initial extent of genetic variation in a population affected the early dynamics of evolution in a new environment, but that effect was eroded as new beneficial mutations swept through the populations. Meanwhile, varying the severity of population bottlenecks had multiple effects on the dynamics of evolution caused by differential losses of diversity, changing numbers of generations between bottlenecks, and altered demographic targets of selection. Deep DNA sequencing of evolving E. coli populations also detected many competing mutations in the same genes while they were extremely rare, allowing these genes to be classified in terms of what types of mutations were adaptive in each case.

 

Intellectual Merit

It is often difficult to tease apart cause and effect in how parasites and pathogens evolve because information about how they spread between different hosts is lacking. This project performed and analyzed carefully designed evolution experiments with several systems that allowed transmission, host characteristics, and other aspects of the environment to be controlled, leading to new insights into the complex feedbacks between evolution and ecology in disease. In addition to these conceptual advances, new techniques for tracking evolution in bacteria and digital organisms were developed that can be used in future studies.

 

Broader Impacts

This project contributed to developing a more diverse and competitive STEM workforce through training undergraduate students, PhD students, and postdoctoral fellows in multidisciplinary research. Better understanding of how pathogen evolvability and host ecology interact to influence disease transmission can benefit public health and society. This knowledge is especially important for predicting the emergence of new diseases and controlling their spread. The researchers engaged with the public to improve scientific literacy by creating a website during the COVID-19 epidemic with interactive simulations demonstrating how transmission and spread would change with different factors.
